resource.name: COVID-19 Case & Death Trends by Date
resource.description:
Case and Death data related to COVID-19. 

*As of April 1, 2022 MODHSS is no longer providing negative test data. As a result we will no longer publish total tests per day* 

Cases are based on the date an individual was tested for COVID-19. Using date tested means counts for most recent dates are likely to change as tests are reported to the the Health Department. Cases include those without an address assigned to KCMO by MODHSS to investigate. Antigen tests are not included at this time.
Deaths are based on the date the death was reported to the Health Department. 

Additional data available in the link below.
Data definitions are also available in the link below.
This dataset will be updated weekly on Wednesday.

Case & death data current as of December 3, 2022
columns_description: date and time
Total number of COVID-19 cases for Kansas City, MO
Total number of deaths due to COVID-19 or where COVID-19 was a significant contributing factor
Number of new deaths due to COVID-19 or where COVID-19 was a significant contributing factor, based on date of death
Number of new COVID-19 cases based on date tested

resource.name: Dangerous Buildings List
resource.description: Updated daily. Dangerous Buildings cases are evaluated in accordance with building code standards to determine if they are a candidate for demolition. Private owners are generally given at least 30 days to conduct work to repair or demolish their property before the City will take action. The more severe the damage, the shorter the timeline the property owner has to avoid City action, which can include municipal court summons, fines, and demolition by City contractors (the cost of which is then assessed against the property owner).
columns_description: Full address of the dangerous building, with City, State, and ZIP.
The Parcel Identification Number (formerly called KIVAPIN) of the parcel on which the dangerous building resides. Unique.
When was the City's case against the dangerous building opened. There may have been earlier cases in other departments.
The ZIP Code of the dangerous building. May be blank if unknown.
The physical address of the dangerous building. May be approximate or a range, for example '2010-2012 Agnes'.
The case number, currently a Service Order in PeopleSoft CRM. 7 digits, sequential, may not be blank.

This column was automatically created in order to record in what polygon from the dataset 'City Council Districts (effective 2023)' (qizh-zmq5) the point in column 'location' is located.  This enables the creation of region maps (choropleths) in the visualization canvas and data lens.

resource.name: Property Violations [Historical]
resource.description: This dataset is historical as of mid-2021. For current property violations, see https://data.kcmo.org/Neighborhoods/Property-Violations-from-EnerGov/vq3e-m9ge
resource.attribution: City of Kansas City Neighborhoods and Housing
columns_description: The Kansas City Ordinance outlining the legal definition of the violation.
Kansas City has defined neighborhood boundaries. This field contains the names of the neighborhood that a property violation is within.
The date that a violation was logged into the case. Cases may be open for several days before a violation is logged.
A brief text description of the violation is contained in this variable.
This variable contains the date that the property violation case was opened.
This variable contains the date that the property violation case was marked as closed. If no date is present the case status is  "Open".
The status of the case is contained here. Cases can either be "Open" or "Closed". "Open" indicates that the violation has not been resolved.

The number of days a case has been opened. Cases that are still open are present and are updated daily. Closed cases will be a static, unchanging number. When looking only at closed cases the number of days open can be used to measure the number of days it took to resolve a case.
KIVA pins are a unique identified ursed by Kansas City to identify properties. You can use these pins at http://kivaweb.kcmo.org/kivanet/2/index.cfm.
This variable contains a geocoded address with a set of coordinates (latitude and longitude) that allow for code violations to be mapped.
Ordinances are cataloged according to chapter. The chapter is the first two digits of the value given in the "Ordinance Number" variable.

resource.name: Community Greenhouse Gas Inventory Data
resource.description: This data set contains communitywide greenhouse gas emissions data in Kansas City, Missouri. This data was used to create the 2013 GHG emissions inventory. See also data sets for government operations and community descriptive characteristics, which was used to create these estimates.

resource.name: 2019 Kansas City Energy and Water Consumption Benchmarking for Community-Wide Buildings
resource.description: The 2019 Energy and Water consumption sent to the City by owners of buildings 50,000 SQFT or greater using the Energy Star Portfolio Manager tool. Data is required by the Energy Empowerment Ordinance in Kansas City, Missouri. The data was collected in 2020 and might be appended as new submissions come in.
columns_description: Direct GHG (low amounts tend to round to 0)

A score generated by the national Energy Star Program used to compare the building to other similar building types. The score is out of 1-100 where 50 is the median and 75 is at the upper quartile. Not all buildings are eligible for a score.
Building name assigned by point of contact for property
Street Address
The zip code the building is located in.
Water metric from indoor, outdoor, and mixed meters
State the building is located in: Missouri
Unique (with a few exceptions) ID that identifies the building being submitted.
A self-selected main property use type
A calculated property use type based of the use that has the most SQFT assigned to it.
Total SQFT between the building and parking
Total building SQFT (does not include parking)
Energy use per SQFT that has been normalized to account for both weather and source of energy
Energy use per SQFT that has been normalized to account for weather. compared to Site, this is more reflective of what you'd find on a utility billing statement.
Indirect GHG (low amounts tend to round to 0)
Total Parking SQFT (does not include building SQFT)
The last date in the full year period in which metrics are taken
City that the building is located in: Kansas City Missouri.

resource.name: Business License Holders
resource.description: A business operating in the city must obtain an occupational license.  This requirement applies to business entities regardless of their size or composition:  corporation, partnership, association, company, individual, or any other type of business arrangement.  A few professions, which are licensed by the state--most notably doctors, dentists, and lawyers--are not required to have occupational licenses.  To verify if you need a business/occupational license, contact the Business License section at (816) 513-1135.

resource.name: KCPD Crime Data 2019
resource.description: This is the most current information as of the date of upload. This provides the user the ability to view the most current crime information within Kansas City, Missouri. The displayed information is the most current information from the data source as of the date of upload. The data source is dynamic and therefore constantly changing. Changes to the information may occur, as incident information is refined. While the Board of Police Commissioners of Kansas City, Missouri (Board) makes every effort to maintain and distribute accurate information, no warranties and/or representations of any kind are made regarding information, data or services provided. The Board is not responsible for misinterpretation of this information and makes no inference or judgment as to the relative safety to any particular area or neighborhood. In no event shall the Board be liable in any way to the users of this data. Users of this data shall hold the Board harmless in all matters and accounts arising from the use and/or accuracy of this data.

columns_description: Where the building is located. Most rows show street address, city, state, zip code, x-coordinate,y-coordinate.

Main property type.

This score is used to rate buildings on a scale of 1-100. The score indicates the energy efficiency percentile the building is in relation to similar properties. Not all building types are eligible.
The site energy use per square foot the property would have consumed during 30-year average weather conditions.
The source energy use the property would have consumed during 30-year average weather conditions.
Total energy cost for the year the data was collected.
Total Water Use for the year the data was collected.

Indirect Emissions are emissions associated with purchases of electricity, district steam, district hot water, or district chilled water. These emissions occur at the utility’s plant, but they are a result of the property’s energy consumption and therefore contribute to the overall GHG footprint.

This column was automatically created in order to record in what polygon from the dataset 'Neighborhood Census' (kk66-ngf4) the point in column 'location' is located. This enables the creation of region maps (choropleths) in the visualization canvas and data lens.

Indirect Emissions are emissions associated with purchases of electricity, district steam, district hot water, or district chilled water. These emissions occur at the utility’s plant, but they are a result of the property’s energy consumption and therefore contribute to the overall GHG footprint. This number is per building square foot.
National median site energy use per square foot. This can be used to compare to the local usage.
Site energy use per square foot.
The ending date for the year the data is collected.

This column was automatically created in order to record in what polygon from the dataset 'Council Districts' (9t2m-phkm) the point in column 'location' is located. This enables the creation of region maps (choropleths) in the visualization canvas and data lens.

National Median for Source Energy Use.

The Electric Emissions Rate conveys the amount of carbon dioxide equivalent (CO2e) emissions associated with the electricity consumption, in kilograms per MBtu. Note that the electric emissions rate depends on where your property is located, EPA uses the average electricity production output emission rate of the electricity grid serving the property, as defined by the Emissions & Generation Resource Integrated Database (eGRID).

Source Energy Use is the total amount of raw fuel that is required to operate the property. In addition to what the property consumes on-site, source energy includes losses that take place during generation, transmission, and distribution of the energy. This number represents per square foot.

Source Energy Use is the total amount of raw fuel that is required to operate the property. In addition to what the property consumes on-site, source energy includes losses that take place during generation, transmission, and distribution of the energy.
% difference between building site EUI and national median site EUI for similar building use types.
National median total site energy use. This can be used to compare to the local usage.
Benchmarking ID created by the City of Kansas City Missouri to identify covered buildings.
Sefl-selected name for the property.
Zip Code for property.
Used for buildings that are part of a campus. This is the name of the main property.
All use types associated with the property.
Total site energy use for the year. Site Energy is the annual amount of all the energy the property consumes onsite, as reported on your utility bills.
The site energy use the property would have consumed during 30-year average weather conditions.
The source energy use per square foot the property would have consumed during 30-year average weather conditions.
Cost per square foot for the year the data was collected.
Direct Emissions are emissions associated with onsite fuel combustion (e.g. combustion of natural gas or fuel oil).
Direct Emissions are emissions associated with onsite fuel combustion (e.g. combustion of natural gas or fuel oil). This amount is per building square foot.
EPA identified eGrid subregion.

resource.name: Energy, Air & Climate Impacts of City-Owned Buildings in Kansas City, MO (2015)
resource.description:
This dataset provides information on large city-owned buildings, including 2015 environmental impacts (energy, water, greenhouse gas emissions) and energy costs, and property characteristics (square feet, year built, property use type). The data was collected and published per the Energy Empowerment Ordinance. 

Energy data is reported in thousand British Thermal Units (kBTU), normalizing all fuel types into a common energy unit.

Read more at http://kcmo.gov/kcgreen/benchmarking/. An annual report with data analysis will be published each December beginning in 2016.
resource.attribution: City of Kansas City, City Manager's Office/Office of Environmental Quality
columns_name: % Difference from National Median Site EUI
Direct Greenhouse Gas Emissions (Metric Tons CO2e)
National Median Total GHG Emissions (Metric Tons CO2e)

% Difference from National Median Source EUI
Indirect Greenhouse Gas Emissions (Metric Tons CO2e)

resource.name: Vendor Payments Calendar Year 2011
resource.description: A data set of all payments made to vendors in 2011. Checkbook level data. When analyzing this data be aware that the sum amount and voucher are unique amounts, the payment amount is the total of a check. A check often includes more than one voucher. As a result of the Red Flag Commission recommendations, Ordinance 970032 was passed by the City Council Jan. 23, 1997. This ordinance requires the city to publish a report every two weeks listing all city payments.

resource.name: Buildings
resource.description: list of buildings, housefacts

resource.name: Capital Improvements 1996 to 2020
resource.description: LISTING OF PROJECTS IN THE CITY'S CAPITAL IMPROVEMENTS BUDGET AND THEIR CHARACTERISTICS - Data comes from annual Capital Budgets. Many projects are listed more than once, because they appeared in more than one budget report. It is best to use "Year 1" costs only for each respective budget year to avoid double counting or use of costs that later changed. Projects with no costs in Year 1 should usually be excluded, because they may have never come to fruition. There are also separate items for each project fund. Projects are not listed separately if they were part of multiple-location projects that appeared as a single line item in a budget.

resource.name: City Planning and Development Department Analysis Implementation Status
resource.description: In an effort to provide exceptional service to the community and the department’s customers, a comprehensive evaluation and review of the City Planning and Development Department’s current business service processes and performance was conducted by Zucker and Associates beginning in December 2013. The goal of the analysis was to provide a framework for exceptional service while fulfilling the development needs of the community and recognizing the high standards expected by the citizens and elected officials. This data set will be updated periodically to reflect the most recent activity and implementation status.
resource.attribution: City Planning and Development Department - Kansas City, Missouri
columns_name: Count Column for Open Data Rollups
columns_description: "Yes" indicates that the recommendation has been implemented.
"Yes" indicates that the recommendation is currently being addressed.
Latest updates as submitted by those in charge of a recommendations implementation.
The date that a recommendation status was set.
Which City Planning and Development Division will address this recommendation.
The recommendation number is used as a row identifier.
"Yes" indicates that the recommendation has begun to be addressed.
"Yes" indicates that the recommendation will need to wait for the EnerGov software system to launch before it can be fully implemented.
The text of the recommendation from the report.
Recommendation Status. This column is created via a formula in excel, and is an add-on to the original data.
This column is here so that you can roll-up (aka pivot) data in Socrata and the code can add sum columns together to generate a count.

resource.name: KCMO Food Permits
resource.description:
All food establishments in the City that serve food must be permitted annually and inspected regularly by the Food Protection Program.

For additional information regarding permits or inspections, please call 816-513-6315.

Establishments required to be permitted and inspected:

Restaurants and Bars
Grocery Stores
Convenience Stores
Concession Stands
Ice Cream Trucks
Push Carts
Mobile Units
Frozen Truck Vendors
Seasonal Permits

resource.name: Demolished Dangerous Buildings
resource.description: This is a list of buildings that were once on the dangerous buildings list (https://data.kcmo.org/Property/Dangerous-Buildings-List/ax3m-jhxx)  but have been demolished. Once a structure is demolished it is removed from the dangerous buildings list.

metadata.license: Open Data Commons Open Database License

resource.name: City-Level Descriptive Statistics for GHG Inventory
resource.description:
This data set contains community statistics that were used to calculate greenhouse gas emissions (GHG) for the purposes of the 2013 GHG inventory.

Data sources include US Census Bureau, Mid-America Regional Council (MARC), Jackson County Assessor Office, KCP&L electric company, Missouri Gas/Laclede gas company, Federal Highway Administration Office of Highway Policy Information Highway Statistics Series, Climate Action and Climate Protection Software notes, Kansas City Area Transit Authority (KCATA), EPA flight and large emitter website (http://ghgdata.epa.gov), City of Kansas City PUblic Words and Water Services Departments

resource.name: Permits - Core Dataset
resource.description:
This dataset contains Permits from the CompassKC system. It is structured according to the Building & Land Development Specification. Specifically, this dataset is the "core" portion of the standard. Information about the standard can be found here:

https://github.com/open-data-standards/permitdata.org/wiki/Core-Permits-Dataset-Requirements

Fields listed in the standard, but not present in this dataset are unavailable because Kansas City, Missouri does not collect or create this information.

Dataset updates automatically at 1:30AM every day.
resource.attribution: Department of City Planning - City of Kansas City, Missoui

resource.name: Vendor Payments Calendar Year 2020
resource.description:
A data set of payments made to vendors in 2020. Checkbook level data. When analyzing this data be aware that the sum amount and voucher are unique amounts, the payment amount is the total of a check. A check often includes more than one voucher.
As a result of the Red Flag Commission recommendations, Ordinance 970032 was passed by the City Council Jan. 23, 1997. This ordinance requires the city to publish a report every two weeks listing all city payments.
resource.attribution: City of Kansas City Finance Department

resource.name: Property Violations from EnerGov
resource.description: Property violations (Chapter 56/48 of the Kansas City Code of Ordinances) are primarily residential, exterior violations that are seen to create nuisances, danger, or otherwise detract from the health and safety of the neighborhood in which they occur. Inspectors follow a process to inspect, advise of violations, reinspect, and take enforcement actions if necessary
columns_description: if not blank, the date the violation was found to be corrected. if blank, violation_status should still indicate that it is open

ordinance of the violation
actions to be taken to alleviate the violation , according to the warning letter
unique numerical identifier for the parcel where the violation occurs
full geospatial address for mapping violation location
case number from EnerGov associated with this violation and address
unique identifier for the violation (GUID)
ordinance-mandated date that the violation should be corrected by, according to the warning letter
ZIP Code of violation location
status of the EnerGov case
a one-phrase description of the ordinance

resource.name: KCPD Crime Data 2020
resource.description: This is the most current information as of the date of upload. This provides the user the ability to view the most current crime information within Kansas City, Missouri. The displayed information is the most current information from the data source as of the date of upload. The data source is dynamic and therefore constantly changing. Changes to the information may occur, as incident information is refined. While the Board of Police Commissioners of Kansas City, Missouri (Board) makes every effort to maintain and distribute accurate information, no warranties and/or representations of any kind are made regarding information, data or services provided. The Board is not responsible for misinterpretation of this information and makes no inference or judgment as to the relative safety to any particular area or neighborhood. In no event shall the Board be liable in any way to the users of this data. Users of this data shall hold the Board harmless in all matters and accounts arising from the use and/or accuracy of this data.

resource.name: Count of LEED Certified Buildings In Kansas City by Certification Level, 2006-2016
Litter Index
resource.description: The Litter Index is a sophisticated tool designed by Keep America Beautiful, which is in use across the nation to measure the amount of visible litter in a community.  Teams of volunteers drive through communities and survey a random, statistical sample of five percent of all street segments in the city. Then Geographic Information Systems (GIS) software is used to map the results.

resource.name: 2010-2016 Building Permit Listing
resource.description: LISTING OF BUILDING PERMITS FOR NEW CONSTRUCTION, DEMOLITION AND ADDITIONS/ALTERATIONS/REPAIRS AND THEIR CHARACTERISTICS - Before 2009, files capture permits only for basic structural work. From 2009 onward, they also capture permits for plumbing, electrical, etc. This results in higher dollar figures and numbers of permits for Additions, Alterations and Repairs and for New Construction. There is no change in how housing units are counted.

resource.name: KCPD Crime Data 2014
resource.description:
This is the most current information as of the date of upload. This provides the user the ability to view the most current crime information within Kansas City, Missouri.  The displayed information is the most current information from the data source as of the date of upload.  The data source is dynamic and therefore constantly changing.  Changes to the information may occur, as incident information is refined.

While the Board of Police Commissioners of Kansas City, Missouri (Board) makes every effort to maintain and distribute accurate information, no warranties and/or representations of any kind are made regarding information, data or services provided.  The Board is not responsible for misinterpretation of this information and makes no inference or judgment as to the relative safety to any particular area or neighborhood.  In no event shall the Board be liable in any way to the users of this data.  Users of this data shall hold the Board harmless in all matters and accounts arising from the use and/or accuracy of this data.
